subject: Re: Does Static Invocation call setUp()/tearDown()?
msgSnippet: ... Thanks for the suggestion. Once again, it was so obvious I didn t see it. Doh! ... I m all for that! ... That s what I meant. Sorry I wasn t clearer. ...
messageBody:
> > It does not keep them from being invoked, but they only get invoked
> > once per TestCase, not before and after each test method. Perhaps I
> > was not clear when I stated what I was looking for. I want the behavior
> > that is:
> >
> > setUp() -> first test -> tearDown()
> > setUp() -> next test -> tearDown()
> > ...
> > setUp() -> last test -> tearDown()
> >
> > But overriding runTest() produces:
> >
> > setUp() -> first test -> next test -> last test -> tearDown()
>
> STOOOOOOOOOP! What you have to do is really simple:
>
> - forget everything you know about runTest
>
> - write your TestCases the old fashion way:
>
> public void MyTest extends TestCase {
> protected void setUp() { /* ... */ }
> protected void tearDown() { /* ... */ }
>
> public void testFirst() { /* ... */ }
> public void testSecond() { /* ... */ }
> }

Thanks for the suggestion. Once again, it was so obvious I
didn't see it. Doh!

> keep it simple :-)

I'm all for that!

> > Only calling setUp() once before all testXXX() methods, and
> > tearDown() once after all testXXX() methods.
>
> You don't have to call anything, the framework does it for you.

That's what I meant. Sorry I wasn't clearer.

> > As far as the name passed to the TestCase not being the test method
> > name, that does work as in my example, if you override runTest().
>
> yes, if you overwrite runTest(). But this is not how JUnit is
> supposed to work (well AFAIK).

As previously stated, I am aware it is rarely used this way, but
this was a question for understanding, not necessarily practicality.

> > Once again, lest y'all think I'm completely nuts, I wasn't advocating
> > this approach, just trying to understand the behavior since it is
> > both possible and documented in the JUnit files.
>
> I see what you mean. The "problem" is that the documentation
> presents how the framework was developed (from day one) and it also
> presents options that IMO make little sense with the finished
> framework (like overwriting the runTest method) but not when the
> framework was young and immature.

I guess the historical angle had not occurred to me. That's an
interesting point of view. I will try to "refactor" my thinking
with this in mind and see if that changes my mind about how
static invocation works.

> Ok, don't start flaming me and presenting 10,000 good resons to
> overwrite runTest, please :-)

Never! You've been very insightful.

Thanks, Derek
